review.title: Dependency resolution and semantic mining using Tree Adjoining Grammars for Tamil Language
review.abstract: Tree adjoining grammars (TAGs) provide an ample tool to capture syntax of many Indian languages. Tamil represents a special challenge to computational formalisms as it has extensive agglutinative morphology and a comparatively difficult argument structure. Modelling Tamil syntax and morphology using TAG is an interesting problem which has not been in focus even though TAGs are over 4 decades old, since its inception. Our research with Tamil TAGs have shown us that we can not only represent syntax of the language, but to an extent mine out semantics through dependency resolution of the sentence. But in order to demonstrate this phenomenal property, we need to parse Tamil language sentences using TAGs we have built and through parsing obtain a derivation we could use to resolve dependencies, thus proving the semantic property. We use an in-house developed pseudo lexical TAG chart parser; algorithm given by Schabes and Joshi (1988), for generating derivations of sentences. We do not use any statistics to rank out ambiguous derivations but rather use all of them to understand the mentioned semantic relation with in TAGs for Tamil. We shall also present a brief parser analysis for the completeness of our discussions.

metadata.title: Dependency resolution and semantic mining using Tree Adjoining Grammars for Tamil Language

sections.text: Modelling Tamil syntax and morphology using TAG is an interesting problem that is not in focus, although TAGs have been around for more than four decades since their inception. However, our research with Tamil TAGs has shown us that we can not only represent the syntax of language, but also, to some extent, work out the semantics by dissolving the dependence of the sentence. However, to demonstrate this phenomenal property, we need to analyze Tamil language sentences using TAGs that we have developed, and by parsing we obtain a derivative that we can use to resolve dependencies and thus prove the semantic property. We use an in-house pseudo-lexical TAG diagram parser; an algorithm given by Schabes and Joshi (1988) to generate derivatives of sentences. We do not use statistics to classify ambiguous derivations, but use them all to understand the short Tamil relationship that Shabes and Joshi (1988) have.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: TAGs are one of the main motivations for researching TAGs, both linguistically and semantically, and the phenomena are now presented in many formal forms. Contrary to Chomskian formalisms, the elementary objects manipulated by TAG are trees. Such structured formalisms have properties that directly relate to a strong generative capacity (structural descriptions) that are more linguistically relevant than string sentences (weak generative capacity). So we call TAGs a tree-generating system that has properties that directly relate to a strong generative capacity. The sentence of all trees derived in an object language is the object language. Hence, to describe the derivation of an object language, we will need to know about "derivative trees." The derivative trees are important both syntactically and semantically. TAGs also have some interesting linguistic properties.
